mKvPuDzR.title: Intracisternal increase of superoxide anion production in a canine subarachnoid hemorrhage model.
mKvPuDzR.abstract: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are thought to be primary in the pathogenesis of cerebral vasospasm after subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). However, as direct evidence of ROS has not yet been demonstrated in cerebral vasospasm, we sought to substantiate superoxide anion (.O(2)(-)) generation in the subarachnoid space after SAH using a modification of Karnovsky's manganese/diaminobenzidine (Mn(2+)/DAB) technique.SAH or sham operation was induced according to a 2-hemorrhage model in a total of 24 beagle dogs. On day 2 or 7 after SAH or sham operation, dogs were intrathecally infused with buffer containing Mn(2+) and DAB, and the brain stem was prepared for light and electron microscopy. Possible colocalization of ferrous (Fe(2+)) or ferric (Fe(3+)) iron ions with.O(2)(-) was also examined with the use of Turnbull blue or Berlin blue staining, respectively.Light microscopy revealed amorphous, amber deposits within the subarachnoid hematoma, the periarterial space, and the tunica adventitia of the basilar artery on days 2 and 7 after SAH.O(2)(-) deposits were eliminated by addition of superoxide dismutase or exclusion of either Mn(2+) or DAB from the perfusate, confirming the specificity of the reaction. These deposits were colocalized with blue reaction deposits indicating Fe(2+) and Fe(3+). Within the subarachnoid space,.O(2)(-) indicating electron-dense fine granules were preferentially located around degenerated erythrocytes and, secondarily, infiltrating macrophages and neutrophils.We show direct evidence for enhanced production of.O(2)(-) and Fe(2+)/Fe(3+) iron ions in the subarachnoid space after SAH, lending further support to the pathogenic role of ROS in cerebral vasospasm after SAH.
keywords: reactive oxygen species n subarachnoid hemorrhage n superoxides n vasospasm
mKvPuDzR.venue: Stroke; a journal of cerebral circulation

9Yg0p12h.title: Rapamycin promotes β-amyloid production via ADAM-10 inhibition
9Yg0p12h.abstract: Rapamycin is a well known immunosuppressant drug for rejection prevention in organ transplantation. Numerous clinical trials using rapamycin analogs, involving both children and adults with various disorders are currently ongoing worldwide. Most recently, rapamycin gained much attention for what appears to be life-span extending properties when administered to mice. The risk for Alzheimer disease (AD) is strongly and positively correlated with advancing age and is characterized by deposition of β-amyloid peptides (Aβ) as senile plaques in the brain. We report that rapamycin (2.5 μM), significantly increases Aβ generation in murine neuron-like cells (N2a) transfected with the human “Swedish” mutant amyloid precursor protein (APP). In concert with these observations, we found rapamycin significantly decreases the neuroprotective amino-terminal APP (amyloid precursor protein) cleavage product, soluble APP-α (sAPP-α) while increasing production of the β-carboxyl-terminal fragment of APP (β-CTF). These cleavage events are associated with decreased activation of a disintegrin and metallopeptidase domain-10 (ADAM-10), an important candidate α-secretase which opposes Aβ generation. To validate these findings in vivo , we intraperitoneal (i.p.) injected Tg2576 Aβ-overproducing transgenic mice with rapamycin (3 mg/kg/day) for 2 weeks. We found increased Aβ levels associated with decreased sAPP-α at an average rapamycin plasma concentration of 169.7 ± 23.5 ng/mL by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). These data suggest that although rapamycin may increase the lifespan in some mouse models, it may not decrease the risk for age-associated neurodegenerative disorders such as AD. Keywords Beta-amyloid Rapamycin Alzheimer’s Abeta ADAM10 Sirolimus Rapamune Aging Neurodegeneration 1 Introduction According to the amyloid cascade hypothesis, abnormal accumulation of Aβ in the brain is a direct cause of neurodegeneration and cognitive decline in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) [1–4] . The hypothesis is supported by the identification of familial mutations of APP (amyloid precursor protein) and presenilins (PS-1, 2) [5–8] . These mutations lead to increased generation of the amyloid-beta (Aβ); and especially the 42-amino acid form (Aβ 1–42 ) displays an increased propensity for aggregation and formation of amyloid plaques and subsequent dementia in humans [9] . More recently, it has been suggested that accumulation of smaller toxic oligomers of Aβ may be more relevant than plaques to mechanisms involved in neurodegeneration and cognitive decline [10,11] . Rapamycin, (i.e. sirolimus, rapamune), is an immunosuppressant drug used to prevent organ rejection, especially in kidney transplantation (review in [12] ). It is a naturally occurring non-antibiotic macrolide compound first discovered over 30 years ago as a product of the bacterium Streptomyces hygroscopicus in a soil sample from Easter Island [13] . Recently, however it has been tested as an anti-aging compound. In a 2009 study, the lifespan of mice fed rapamycin were increased by 28–38% from the beginning of treatment, with a 9–14% total increase in maximum lifespan. Of particular note, the treatment began in mice aged 20 months, the human equivalent of 60 years [14] . This suggests the possibility of an effective anti-aging treatment for humans at an already-advanced age, as opposed to requiring a lifelong regimen beginning in youth. Numerous clinical trials using rapamycin analogs, involving both children and adults with tuberous sclerosis, renal cell carcinoma, breast cancer, lupus and other conditions, are under way in the United States [15] . Previously, it has been shown that inhibition of mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), also known as FK506 binding protein 12-rapamycin associated protein 1 (FRAP1), may have therapeutic potential for neurodegenerative disorders, such as AD, Huntington’s, and Parkinson’s disease possibly through enhancement of autophagy (Reviewed in [16] ). However, we wondered whether rapamycin might also affect APP metabolism. Thus, in our current investigation we hypothesized that rapamycin would decrease Aβ generation. Surprisingly however, rapamycin treatment of murine neuroblastoma cells overexpressing “Swedish” mutant APP695aa isoform (SweAPP N2a) and transgenic Aβ-overproducing mice (Tg2576) lead to increased Aβ generation in vitro and in vivo . The neuroprotective amino-terminal APP cleavage product, soluble APP-α (sAPP-α), likely produced by candidate α-secretase a disintegrin and metallopeptidase domain-10 (ADAM-10; the principle CNS α-secretase [17] ) were both decreased after rapamycin treatment in vitro . In vivo , we found Tg2576 mice intraperitoneal (i.p.) injected with rapamycin (3 mg/kg/day) for 2 weeks resulted in increased Aβ levels associated with inhibition of α-secretase APP cleavage and decreased ADAM-10 at an average rapamycin plasma level of 169.7 ± 23.5 ng/mL by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Reagents Rapamycin powder (99% purity by HPLC), was purchased from LC Lab (Woburn, MA). Aβ and sAPP-α ELISA kits were obtained from Calbiochem (San Diego, CA). Antibodies against ADAM-17, BACE1, PS-1 (C-terminus antibody) and β-actin were purchased from Calbiochem. Antibodies against the C-terminus (Sigma, St. Louis, MO), and N-terminus (22C11, Roche, Basel, Switzerland) of APP were obtained. Antibodies 6E10 and 4G8 against Aβ were purchased from Covance (Princeton, NJ). Antibodies against ADAM-10 were a kind gift from Dr. Bart De Strooper (KUL, VIP, Leuven, Belgium). 2.2 SweAPP N2a cell culture Murine N2a cells were purchased (ATCC, Manassas, VA) and cultured in complete DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum and 1% Geneticin (G418; 40 mg/mL, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). Cells were plated in 12-well collagen-coated culture plates at a density of 2 × 10 5 cells per well. After overnight incubation, N2a cells were incubated in neurobasal media (Invitrogen) supplemented with 3 mM dibutyryl cAMP (Sigma) for terminal differentiation in preparation for treatment. 2.3 Mice Transgenic mice overexpressing “Swedish” mutant APP695aa isoform driven by prion promoter (line 2576, Tg2576) were purchased from Taconic (Germantown, NY). For i.p. administration of rapamycin, a total of 10 female Tg2576 mice were used: 5 mice received rapamycin, and 5 control mice received PBS. Beginning at 4 months of age, Tg2576 mice were i.p. injected with rapamycin (3 mg/kg) or PBS for 2 weeks (5 days/week), based on methods described previously [18] . Briefly, rapamycin (LC Labs) was initially dissolved in 100% EtOH, stored at −20 °C, and diluted in a vehicle solution containing 5% Tween 80, 5% PEG 400 (Sigma), and 4% EtOH immediately before injection. After 2 weeks, these mice were euthanized. Murine brains were isolated under sterile conditions on ice and placed in ice-cold lysis buffer (20 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 1 mM EDTA, 1 mM EGTA, 1% v/v Triton X-100, 2.5 mM sodium pyrophosphate, 1 mM β-glycerolphosphate, 1 mM Na 3 VO 4 , 1 μg/mL leupeptin, 1 mM PMSF). Brains were then sonicated on ice for approximately 3 min, allowed to stand for 15 min at 4 °C, and centrifuged at 15,000 rpm for 15 min. Next we collected the supernatants for analyses of Aβ levels in the brain according to methods described previously [19] . 2.4 ELISA Quantitation of total Aβ and sAPP-α was performed according to our published methods [19] . 2.5 Western blot Cultured cells or mouse brains were lysed in ice-cold lysis buffer as described previously [20] . All antibodies were diluted in TBS containing 5% (w/v) nonfat dry milk. Blots were developed using the Luminol reagent (Pierce). Densitometric analysis was done as described previously using a FluorS Multiimager with Quantity One software (Bio-Rad) [19] . Antibodies used for western analysis included the C-terminal APP (1:500; Sigma), N-terminal APP (clone 22C11, Roche), N-terminal Aβ 6E10 (1:1000; Covance), ADAM-10 (1:500), ADAM-17 (1:500; Calbiochem), BACE1 (1:500; Calbiochem), PS-1 (C-terminal antibody; 1:500; Calbiochem), and β-actin (1:1500; as an internal reference control; Calbiochem). 2.6 Immunoprecipitation Immunoprecipitation (IP) was performed for detection of sAPP-α and Aβ in cultured cell medium and for detection of β-CTF in cell lysates as previously [20] . Next, samples were subjected to western analysis as described above. 2.7 HPLC analysis Because rapamycin was administered i.p., we determined rapamycin concentration in mice blood before they were decapitated. Five-hundred to 800 mL of murine blood was extracted from the right ventricle. After centrifuge at 14,000 rpm at 4 °C, rapamycin concentration in the serum was determined by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). All HPLC analysis was performed on Bio-Rad Dio Flow HPLC System with the following parameters. Flow rate: 0.8 mL/min, λ (Wavelength): 278 nm, Column: Supelco C8, 5 μm pore size, (25 cm × 4.6 mm), Mobile Phase: [80:20:0.1%] − [ACN:H 2 O:acetic acid], Run time: 15 min, rapamycin Retention Time (RT): 9.7 min. Rapamycin was extracted from 100 μL of plasma using a triple sample volume of chloroform (300 μL) and vortexing for 3 min. Samples were centrifuged for 1 min to separate the chloroform layer, which was removed and evaporated under vacuum for 20 min. Sample residues were re-suspended into 400 μL of mobile phase for analysis. 2.8 Statistical analysis All data were normally distributed; therefore, in instances of single mean comparisons, Levene’s test for equality of variances followed by a t -test for independent samples were used to assess significance. In instances of multiple mean comparisons, ANOVA was used, followed by post hoc comparison using Bonferonni’s method were used. Alpha was set at 0.05 for all analyses. The statistical package for the social sciences release 18.0.0 (SPSS, Chicago, IL) was used for all data analyses. 3 Results 3.1 Rapamycin promotes Aβ generation from SweAPP N2a cells To examine the effects of rapamycin on Aβ production, we treated SweAPP N2a cells with a wide dose range of rapamycin. We found that it increased Aβ generation in cultured SweAPP N2a cells dose-dependently. At the 5 μM dose, rapamycin increased Aβ generation by almost sevenfold compared to untreated controls by Aβ ELISA ( Fig. 1 A). These results were also confirmed by immunoprecipitation and western blotting ( Fig. 1 B and C). 3.2 Rapamycin promotes amyloidogenic processing of APP in SweAPP N2a cells by inhibiting ADAM-10 expression To elucidate the mode of action of rapamycin on APP cleavage, we examined APP cleavage profiles after treatment of SweAPP N2a cells with rapamycin using ELISA, western and IP analyses. In concert with increased Aβ generation, rapamycin treatment leads to enhanced generation of β-CTF and decreased sAPP-α ( Fig. 1c, 2 A and B). These results suggest that α-secretase activity was inhibited. In order to test this, we characterized two important candidates of α-secretase, ADAM-10 and ADAM-17 (TACE), and found that only ADAM-10 was inhibited by rapamycin treatment ( Fig. 2 C), but ADAM-17 was not affected (data not shown). We also examined β-secretase (BACE-1) and PS-1 by western analysis, and found no difference in treated and control groups (data not shown). It should be noted that we did not observe significant changes in full-length holo APP expression after rapamycin treatment ( Fig. 1 C), suggesting that rapamycin treatment predominantly inhibits non-amyloidogenic APP cleavage, without modulating APP expression in SweAPP N2a cells. 3.3 Rapamycin increases Aβ generation in Tg2576 mouse brains via ADAM-10 inhibition We validated in vivo whether rapamycin treatment could inhibit non-amyloidogenic APP processing (α-secretase proteolysis) and impact cerebral Aβ levels in AD transgenic mice. We i.p. administered rapamycin to 4 month old Tg2576 mice, a well-established transgenic mouse model of AD [21] . Rapamycin was administered based on a treatment schedule that produces benefit in a tuberous sclerosis mouse model (3 mg/kg) [18] . Tg2576 mice at 4 months of age were i.p. injected with rapamycin or PBS 5 days/week for 2 weeks (10 days total). Aβ levels were markedly increased in brain homogenate of Tg2576 mice treated with rapamycin versus PBS ( Fig. 3 A and B). Specifically, Aβ levels are elevated by 79 ± 20% above PBS-treated mice, by ELISA. In concert with the Aβ elevation, we found that ADAM-10 in brain homogenate of Tg2576 mice was significantly inhibited in the rapamycin treatment group, compared with PBS controls ( Fig. 3 C). Because rapamycin was administered i.p., we determined rapamycin concentration in mice blood before they were decapitated. Five-hundred to 800 mL of murine blood was extracted from the right ventricle. After centrifuge at 14,000 rpm at 4 °C, rapamycin concentration in the serum was determined by HPLC. Results showed the average plasma level of rapamycin was 169.7 ± 23.5 ng/mL. 4 Discussion Traditionally used as an immunosuppressant, rapamycin appears to also display anti-aging properties in mice which would represent an important therapeutic for AD patients if similarly active in humans (reviewed in [16] ). This is not surprising considering its anti-inflammatory effects [22] . However, current investigation, originally aiming to determine expected beneficial effects of rapamycin on Aβ generation suggest that rapamycin can promote Aβ generation not only in vitro , but also in the Tg2576 mouse brain. This raises the question of whether rapamycin can exacerbate Aβ-related pathological changes in AD patients. Recently, contrary to our findings here, in the PDAPP mouse model of AD, investigators found reduced Aβ in the brains of these mice. These findings were associated with enhanced autophagy [23] . However, despite these findings, and the anti-inflammatory effects of rapamycin which may delay aging processes and enhance clearance mechanisms (autophagy) in certain mice, rapamycin-associated Aβ generation may ultimately prevail and lead to increased accumulation of toxic small oligomeric Aβ species once clearance mechanisms in AD patients inevitably falter. Previous theories that Aβ is only a marker of AD, and not an etiologic component of cognitive dysfunction, have changed in the 1990s with the articulation of the amyloid cascade hypothesis [1–4] . This is further epidemiologically supported by the identification of mutations in APP and PS-1,2 that increase Aβ generation and are associated with early cognitive deficits [5–8] . Fundamentally, the amyloidogenic pathway provides for Aβ peptides produced by the initial action of β-secretase (BACE-1,2) cleavage, which creates an Aβ-containing C-terminal fragment (CTF) known as β-CTF [24] . This proteolysis also generates an N-terminal, soluble APP-β (sAPP-β) fragment, which is released extracellularly. Intracellularly, β-CTF is then cleaved by a multiprotein γ-secretase complex that results in generation of Aβ peptides and a smaller γ-CTF [25,26] . Conversely, in the non-amyloidogenic pathway, APP is first cleaved at the α-secretase site, which results in the release of N-terminal sAPP-α and the generation of α-CTF without Aβ production [27,28] . Because of the limiting amount of APP in the cell and the failure to saturate the BACE pathway during APP overexpression, it is believed that the above-mentioned amyloidogenic and non-amyloidogenic pathways compete for substrate in the process of APP proteolysis [29] . Therefore, it is often inferred that extracellular decrease of sAPP-α can be taken as a direct evidence of inhibition of α-secretase and the associated non-amyloidogenic pathway. Our data suggest that rapamycin-associated Aβ generation ( Fig. 1 A and B) corresponded to inhibition of the non-amyloidgenic α-secretase pathway; as sAPP-α in cultured SweAPP N2a cell media was greatly reduced by rapamycin ( Fig. 2 A and B). Further, β-CTF, a product of the amyloidogenic pathway, was also elevated in these cells ( Fig. 1 C). Because APP metabolites arise from the coordinated actions of α-, β-, and γ-secretases, any change to these secretases will result in alterations in Aβ generation. Thus, we next screened putative secretases including ADAM-10, ADAM-17, BACE-1, and PS-1 and found that Aβ generation in rapamycin treated SweAPP N2a cells and Tg2576 mouse brains was associated predominantly with the inhibition of ADAM-10, an important candidate α-secretase in the central nervous system ( Figs. 2 and 3 C, data not shown). Dramatic reductions in the mature active form were observed after rapamycin treatment in vitro ( Fig. 2 C). Moreover, inhibition of α-secretase activity by rapamycin could be counteracted by α-secretase promoting green tea-derived epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG; data not shown) [19] . How rapamycin inhibits ADAM-10 is currently a key question. What is known about rapamycin’s mechanism of action comprises its ability to bind the cytosolic protein FK-binding protein 12 (FKBP12) in a manner similar to tacrolimus. However, unlike the tacrolimus-FKBP12 complex which inhibits calcineurin (PP2B), the rapamycin-FKBP12 complex inhibits the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway by directly binding the mTOR Complex-1 (mTORC-1) [12,30] . Combination therapy with doxorubicin and rapamycin has been shown to drive Akt-positive lymphomas into remission in mice. Akt signaling promotes cell survival in Akt-positive lymphomas and acts to prevent the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy drugs like doxorubicin or cyclophosphamide. Rapamycin blocks Akt signaling causing malignant cells to lose their resistance to the chemotherapy. Bcl-2-positive lymphomas – which effectively subvert Akt regulation – were completely resistant to rapamycin, as were eIF4E-expressing lymphomas [31–33] . Similarly, ADAM-10, an important player in progression of some cancers [34] , may be inhibited by rapamycin through down-regulation of mTOR/Akt signaling. Akt may be able to alter APP phosphorylation/maturation directly or through Shc, [35,36] thereby modulating substrate-mediated ADAM-10 activation [37] . Further evidence is required to support these proposed mechanisms. Recently, it was reported that rapamycin can exacerbate neurotoxicity of Aβ peptides; and that the mTOR pathway is important for the survival of Aβ exposed cells [38] . These previous studies, as well as our current data, suggest that although rapamycin possesses anti-inflammatory and life-extending properties in mice, it may have potential detrimental side-effects if used as monotherapy to treat AD patients. UeA7zDhI.title: Human Umbilical Cord Blood Serum-derived α-Secretase: Functional Testing in Alzheimer's Disease Mouse Models.
UeA7zDhI.abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an age-related disorder that affects cognition. Our previous studies showed that the neuroprotective fragment of amyloid procurer protein (APP) metabolite, soluble APPα (sAPPα), interferes with β-site APP-cleaving enzyme 1 (BACE1, β-secretase) cleavage and reduces amyloid-β (Aβ) generation. In an attempt to identify approaches to restore sAPPα levels, we found that human cord blood serum (CBS) significantly promotes sAPPα production compared with adult blood serum (ABS) and aged blood serum (AgBS) in Chinese hamster ovary cells stably expressing wild-type human APP. Interestingly, CBS selectively mediated the α-secretase cleavage of human neuron-specific recombinant APP in a cell-free system independent of tumor necrosis factor-α converting enzyme (TACE; a disintegrin and metalloproteinase domain-containing protein 17 [ADAM17]) and ADAM. Subsequently, using 3-step chromatographic separation techniques (i.e., diethylaminoethanol, size-exclusion, and ion-exchange chromatography), we purified and ultimately identified a CBS-specific fraction with enhanced α-secretase catalytic activity (termed αCBSF) and found that αCBSF has more than 3,000-fold increased α-secretase catalytic activity compared with the original pooled CBS. Furthermore, intracerebroventricular injection of αCBSF markedly increased cerebral sAPPα levels together with significant decreases in cerebral Aβ production and abnormal tau (Thr) phosphorylation compared with the AgBS fraction with enhanced α-secretase activity (AgBSF) treatment in triple transgenic Alzheimer's disease (3xTg-AD) mice. Moreover, AgBSF administered intraperitoneally to transgenic mice with five familial Alzheimer's disease mutations (5XFAD) via an osmotic mini pump for 6 weeks (wk) ameliorated β-amyloid plaques and reversed cognitive impairment measures. Together, our results propose the necessity for further study aimed at identification and characterization of α-secretase in CBS for novel and effective AD therapy.

jW70hdTG.title: C1q as a Regulator of Brain Development: Implications for Autism SpectrumDisorders
jW70hdTG.abstract: Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) represents a heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental disorders with similar core features of social and communication impairments, restricted interests and repetitive behaviors. Early synaptic dysfunction due to neuroinflammatory insults may underpin the pathogenesis of abnormal brain development in some of individuals with ASDs. As a critical component of the innate immune response, the complement system comprises both directly acting factors and factors that augment other components of the immune system. Beyond its involvement with innate immune responses in the brain, the complement system also plays important roles in neurodevelopment. Recent studies suggest involvement of complement component C1q in fundamental neurodevelopmental pathways and in maintenance and elimination of dendrites and synapses. The impact of aberrant complement system activity during critical windows of brain development may not only affect the local immune response but lead to atypical brain development. This review summarizes and critically analyzes the evidence of a role for the complement system in the pathogenesis of ASDs.

lCIKXLrL.title: CD45 isoform RB as a molecular target to oppose lipopolysaccharide-induced microglial activation in mice
lCIKXLrL.abstract: CD45 is a membrane-bound protein tyrosine phosphatase expressed on all hemopoietic cells with multiple splice variants, including RA, RB, RC and RO. Our previous studies have shown that cross-linking of CD45 with an anti-CD45 antibody markedly inhibits LPS-induced microglia activation. In order to determine which of the CD45 isoforms may be responsible for these effects, we have investigated the expression of CD45 isoforms on cultured microglial cells using flow cytometric analysis. Data reveal that CD45RB is the predominant isoform expressed in murine primary cultured microglial cells. Furthermore, incubation of these cultured cells with anti-CD45RB antibody results in a reduction of microglial activation induced by LPS as evidenced by TNF-alpha production. As a validation of these findings in vivo, brain homogenates from anti-CD45RB antibody (MG23G2)-injected animals that had been treated with LPS demonstrate a significant decrease in TNF-alpha levels compared to control mice treated with LPS plus vehicle. Taken together, these findings suggest that therapeutic agents that specifically stimulate the microglial CD45RB signaling pathway may be effective in suppressing microglial activation associated with several neurodegenerative disorders.

hZK5eUxZ.title: Eukaryotic initiation factor 3, subunit C silencing inhibits cell proliferation and promotes apoptosis in human ovarian cancer cells.
hZK5eUxZ.abstract: Ovarian cancer remains the leading cause of death among all gynaecological cancers, illustrating the urgent need to understand the molecular mechanisms involved in this disease. Eukaryotic initiation factor 3c (EIF3c) plays an important role in protein translation and cancer cell growth and proliferation, but its role in human ovarian cancer is unclear. Our results showed that EIF3c silencing significantly upregulated 217 and downregulated 340 genes. IPA analysis indicated that the top differentially expressed genes are involved in "Classical Pathways", "Diseases and Functions" and "Networks", especially those involved in signalling and cellular growth and proliferation. In addition, eIF3c silencing inhibited cellular proliferation, enhanced apoptosis and regulated the expression of apoptosis-associated proteins. In conclusion, these results indicate that by dysregulating translational initiation, eIF3c plays an important role in the proliferation and survival of human ovarian cancer cells. These results should provide experimental directions for further in-depth studies of important human ovarian cancer cell pathways.

n2YpDS26.title: Neuronal expression of CD22: novel mechanism for inhibiting microglial proinflammatory cytokine production.
n2YpDS26.abstract: Although considered an immunologically privileged site, the central nervous system (CNS) can display significant inflammatory responses, which may play a pathogenic role in a number of neurological diseases. Microglia appear to be particularly important for initiating and sustaining CNS inflammation. These cells exist in a quiescent form in the normal CNS, but acquire macrophage-like properties (including active phagocytosis, upregulation of proteins necessary for antigen presentation, and production of proinflammatory cytokines) after stimulation with inflammatory substances such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS). Recent studies have focused on elucidating the role of neurons in the regulation of microglial inflammatory responses. In the present study, we demonstrate, using neuron-microglial cocultures, that neurons are capable of inhibiting LPS-induced tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) production by microglia. This inhibition appears to be dependent on secretion of substances at axon terminals, as treatment with the presynaptic calcium channel blocker omega-conotoxin abolishes this inhibitory effect. Moreover, we show that conditioned medium from neuronal cultures similarly inhibits microglial TNF-alpha production, which provides additional evidence that neurons secrete inhibitory substances. We previously demonstrated that the transmembrane protein-tyrosine phosphatase CD45 plays an important role in negatively regulating microglial activation. The recent characterization of CD22 as an endogenous ligand of this receptor led us to investigate whether neurons express this protein. Indeed, we were able to demonstrate CD22 mRNA and protein expression in cultured neurons and mouse brain, using reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and antibody-based techniques. Furthermore, we show that neurons secrete CD22, which functions as an inhibitor of microglial proinflammatory cytokine production.

GDf2v8Cn.title: Low-Density Lipoprotein Receptor-Related Protein-1 (LRP1) C4408R Mutant Promotes Amyloid Precursor Protein (APP) α-Cleavage in Vitro.
GDf2v8Cn.abstract: Previous studies have demonstrated that the low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein-1 (LRP1) plays conflicting roles in Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathogenesis, clearing β-amyloid (Aβ) from the brain while also enhancing APP endocytosis and resultant amyloidogenic processing. We have recently discovered that co-expression of mutant LRP1 C-terminal domain (LRP1-CT C4408R) with Swedish mutant amyloid precursor protein (APPswe) in Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells decreases Aβ production, while also increasing sAPPα and APP α-C-terminal fragment (α-CTF), compared with CHO cells expressing APPswe alone. Surprisingly, the location of this mutation on LRP1 corresponded with the α-secretase cleavage site of APP. Further experimentation confirmed that in CHO cells expressing APPswe or wild-type APP (APPwt), co-expression of LRP1-CT C4408R decreases Aβ and increases sAPPα and α-CTF compared with co-expression of wild-type LRP1-CT. In addition, LRP1-CT C4408R enhanced the unglycosylated form of LRP1-CT and reduced APP endocytosis as determined by flow cytometry. This finding identifies a point mutation in LRP1 which slows LRP1-CT-mediated APP endocytosis and amyloidogenic processing, while enhancing APP α-secretase cleavage, thus demonstrating a potential novel target for slowing AD pathogenesis.

1fxustcX.title: Physiological amyloid-beta clearance in the periphery and its therapeutic potential for Alzheimer’s disease
1fxustcX.abstract: Amyloid-beta (Aβ) plays a pivotal role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The physiological capacity of peripheral tissues and organs in clearing brain-derived Aβ and its therapeutic potential for AD remains largely unknown. Here, we measured blood Aβ levels in different locations of the circulation in humans and mice, and used a parabiosis model to investigate the effect of peripheral Aβ catabolism on AD pathogenesis. We found that blood Aβ levels in the inferior/posterior vena cava were lower than that in the superior vena cava in both humans and mice. In addition, injected I labeled Aβ40 was located mostly in the liver, kidney, gastrointestinal tract, and skin but very little in the brain; suggesting that Aβ derived from the brain can be cleared in the periphery. Parabiosis before and after Aβ deposition in the brain significantly reduced brain Aβ burden without alterations in the expression of amyloid precursor protein, Aβ generating and degrading enzymes, Aβ transport receptors, and AD-type pathologies including hyperphosphorylated tau, neuroinflammation, as well as neuronal degeneration and loss in the brains of parabiotic AD mice. Our study revealed that the peripheral system is potent in clearing brain Aβ and preventing AD pathogenesis. The present work suggests that peripheral Aβ clearance is a valid therapeutic approach for AD, and implies that deficits in the Aβ clearance in the periphery might also contribute to AD pathogenesis.

sdSjDKqZ.title: LED enhances anti-inflammatory effect of .
sdSjDKqZ.abstract: Neuroinflammation is a complex pathological process usually results from abnormal microglial activation, thus, intervention in a microglial stimulation pathway could be a promising approach for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. Luteolin is an important bioflavonoid possesses anti-inflammatory properties, which is widely studied over these years. Light emitting diode (LED) therapy is reported to be a potential therapeutic strategy for many diseases including neurodegenerative diseases. However, little is known about the anti-inflammatory effect of LED therapy on activated microglial cells, even less is known whether there is a synergistic anti-inflammatory effect exist in LED and luteolin therapy. In this study, we aimed to confirm the anti-inflammatory effect of luteolin and LED combination therapy in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-stimulated BV2 microglial cells. We showed that luteolin inhibited LPS-induced cytotoxicity, tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNFα) and interleukin-6 (IL-6) production through modulation of p38 and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK) signaling in BV2 cells. In addition, LED therapy enhanced the anti-inflammatory effect of luteolin. These results suggest that a synergistic effect between luteolin and LED could be a new effective therapy in relieving neuroinflammation.

8xESusbv.title: Restoring Soluble Amyloid Precursor Protein α Functions as a Potential Treatment for Alzheimer's Disease
8xESusbv.abstract: Soluble amyloid precursor protein α (sAPPα), a secreted proteolytic fragment of nonamyloidogenic amyloid precursor protein (APP) processing, is known for numerous neuroprotective functions. These functions include but are not limited to proliferation, neuroprotection, synaptic plasticity, memory formation, neurogenesis, and neuritogenesis in cell culture and animal models. In addition, sAPPα influences amyloid-β (Aβ) production by direct modulation of APP β-secretase proteolysis as well as Aβ-related or unrelated tau pathology, hallmark pathologies of Alzheimeru0027s disease (AD). Thus, the restoration of sAPPα levels and functions in the brain by increasing nonamyloidogenic APP processing and/or manipulation of its signaling could reduce AD pathology and cognitive impairment. It is likely that identification and characterization of sAPPα receptors in the brain, downstream effectors, and signaling pathways will pave the way for an attractive therapeutic target for AD prevention or intervention. © 2016 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.

ggWAF7w4.title: Therapeutic Cocktail Approach for Treatment of Hyperhomocysteinemia in Alzheimer’s Disease:
ggWAF7w4.abstract: In the United States, Alzheimeru0027s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, accompanied by substantial economic and emotional costs. During 2015, more than 15 million family members who provided care to AD patients had an estimated total cost of 221 billion dollars. Recent studies have shown that elevated total plasma levels of homocysteine (tHcy), a condition known as hyperhomocysteinemia (HHcy), is a risk factor for AD. HHcy is associated with cognitive decline, brain atrophy, and dementia; enhances the vulnerability of neurons to oxidative injury; and damages the blood–brain barrier. Many therapeutic supplements containing vitamin B12 and folate have been studied to help decrease tHcy to a certain degree. However, a therapeutic cocktail approach with 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, methyl B12, betaine, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) have not been studied. This novel approach may help target multiple pathways simultaneously to decrease tHcy and its toxicity substantially.

ku6bXHSN.title: LISPRO mitigates |[beta]|-amyloid and associated pathologies in Alzheimer|[rsquo]|s mice
ku6bXHSN.abstract: Lithium has been marketed in the United States of America since the 1970s as a treatment for bipolar disorder. More recently, studies have shown that lithium can improve cognitive decline associated with Alzheimer’s disease (AD). However, the current United States Food and Drug Administration-approved lithium pharmaceutics (carbonate and citrate chemical forms) have a narrow therapeutic window and unstable pharmacokinetics that, without careful monitoring, can cause serious adverse effects. Here, we investigated the safety profile, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutic efficacy of LISPRO (ionic co-crystal of lithium salicylate and l-proline), lithium salicylate, and lithium carbonate (Li2CO3). We found that LISPRO (8-week oral treatment) reduces β-amyloid plaques and phosphorylation of tau by reducing neuroinflammation and inactivating glycogen synthase kinase 3β in transgenic Tg2576 mice. Specifically, cytokine profiles from the brain, plasma, and splenocytes suggested that 8-week oral treatment with LISPRO downregulates pro-inflammatory cytokines, upregulates anti-inflammatory cytokines, and suppresses renal cyclooxygenase 2 expression in transgenic Tg2576 mice. Pharmacokinetic studies indicated that LISPRO provides significantly higher brain lithium levels and more steady plasma lithium levels in both B6129SF2/J (2-week oral treatment) and transgenic Tg2576 (8-week oral treatment) mice compared with Li2CO3. Oral administration of LISPRO for 28 weeks significantly reduced β-amyloid plaques and tau-phosphorylation. In addition, LISPRO significantly elevated pre-synaptic (synaptophysin) and post-synaptic protein (post synaptic density protein 95) expression in brains from transgenic 3XTg-AD mice. Taken together, our data suggest that LISPRO may be a superior form of lithium with improved safety and efficacy as a potential new disease modifying drug for AD.

yslDAK2c.title: Combined treatment with the phenolics (-)-epigallocatechin-3-gallate and ferulic acid improves cognition and reduces Alzheimer-like pathology in mice.
yslDAK2c.abstract: 'Nutraceuticals' are well-tolerated natural dietary compounds with drug-like properties that make them attractive as Alzheimer's disease (AD) therapeutics. Combination therapy for AD has garnered attention following a recent National Institute on Aging mandate, but this approach has not yet been fully validated. In this report, we combined the two most promising nutraceuticals with complementary anti-amyloidogenic properties: the plant-derived phenolics (-)-epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG, an α-secretase activator) and ferulic acid (FA, a β-secretase modulator). We used transgenic mice expressing mutant human amyloid β-protein precursor and presenilin 1 (APP/PS1) to model cerebral amyloidosis. At 12 months of age, we orally administered EGCG and/or FA (30 mg/kg each) or vehicle once daily for 3 months. At 15 months, combined EGCG-FA treatment reversed cognitive impairment in most tests of learning and memory, including novel object recognition and maze tasks. Moreover, EGCG- and FA-treated APP/PS1 mice exhibited amelioration of brain parenchymal and cerebral vascular β-amyloid deposits and decreased abundance of amyloid β-proteins compared with either EGCG or FA single treatment. Combined treatment elevated nonamyloidogenic soluble APP-α and α-secretase candidate and down-regulated amyloidogenic soluble APP-β, β-carboxyl-terminal APP fragment and β-secretase protein expression, providing evidence for a shift toward nonamyloidogenic APP processing. Additional beneficial co-treatment effects included amelioration of neuroinflammation, oxidative stress, and synaptotoxicity. Our findings offer preclinical evidence that combined treatment with EGCG and FA is a promising AD therapeutic approach.

IrqqwD5u.title: Comparing the effect of the novel ionic cocrystal of lithium salicylate proline (LISPRO) with lithium carbonate and lithium salicylate on memory and behavior in female APPswe/PS1dE9 Alzheimer's mice.
IrqqwD5u.abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD) is characterized by progressive decline of cognition and associated neuropsychiatric signs including weight loss, anxiety, depression, agitation, and aggression, which is particularly pronounced in the female gender. Previously, we have shown that a novel ionic co-crystal of lithium salicylate proline (LISPRO) is an improved lithium formulation compared to the carbonate or salicylate form of lithium in terms of safety and efficacy in reducing AD pathology in Alzheimer's mice. The current study is designed to compare the prophylactic effects of LISPRO, lithium carbonate (LC), and lithium salicylate (LS) on cognitive and noncognitive impairments in female transgenic APPswe/PS1dE9 AD mice. Female APPswe/PS1dE9 mice at 4 months of age were orally treated with low-dose LISPRO, LS, or LC for 9 months at 2.25 mmol lithium/kg/day followed by determination of body weight, growth of internal organs, and cognitive and noncognitive behavior. No significant differences in body or internal organ weight, anxiety or locomotor activity were found between lithium treated and untreated APPswe/PS1dE9 cohorts. LISPRO, LC, and LS prevented spatial cognitive decline, as determined by Morris water maze and depression as determined by tail suspension test. In addition, LISPRO treatment was superior in preventing associative memory decline determined by contextual fear conditioning and reducing irritability determined by touch escape test in comparison with LC and LS. In conclusion, low-dose LISPRO, LC, and LS treatment prevent spatial cognitive decline and depression-like behavior, while LISPRO prevented hippocampal-dependent associative memory decline and irritability in APPswe/PS1dE9 mice.

pxDRMKW8.title: Beneficial effects of a pyrroloquinolinequinone-containing dietary formulation on motor deficiency, cognitive decline and mitochondrial dysfunction in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
pxDRMKW8.abstract: Alzheimer's disease (AD), a progressive neurodegenerative disorder, is linked to oxidative stress, altered amyloid precursor protein (APP) proteolysis, tau hyperphosphorylation and the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and neurofibrillary tangles (NFT). A growing body of evidence suggests that mitochondrial dysfunction can be a key promoter of all of these pathologies and predicts that restoration of mitochondrial function might be a potential therapeutic strategy for AD. Therefore, in the present study, we tested the beneficial effect of a nutraceutical formulation Nutrastem II (Nutra II), containing NT020 (a mitochondrial restorative and antioxidant proprietary formulation) and pyrroloquinolinequinone (PQQ, a stimulator of mitochondria biogenesis) in 5XFAD transgenic mice. Animals were fed Nutra II for 12 weeks, starting at 3 months of age, after which behavioral and neuropathological endpoints were determined. The data from behavioral test batteries clearly revealed that dietary supplementation of Nutra II effectively ameliorated the motor deficiency and cognitive impairment of 5XFAD mice. In addition, Nutra II also protected mitochondrial function in 5XFAD mice brain, as evidenced by declined ROS levels and membrane hyperpolarization, together with elevated ATP levels and respiratory states. Interestingly, while Nutra II treatment only slightly reduced soluble Aβ levels, this formulation significantly impacted tau metabolism, as shown by reduced total and phosphorylated tau levels of 5XFAD mouse brain. Taken together, these preclinical findings confirm that mitochondrial function may be a key treatment target for AD and that Nutra II should be further investigated as a potential candidate for AD therapy.

YRmbtf5h.title: Human Cord Blood Serum-Derived APP α-Secretase Cleavage Activity is Mediated by C1 Complement.
YRmbtf5h.abstract: Alzheimer's Disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia in the elderly. In healthy individuals, amyloid precursor protein (APP) is cleaved by α-secretase, generating soluble α-amyloid precursor protein (sAPPα), which contributes neuroprotective functions in the neuronal environment. In contrast, in the neurodegenerative environment of AD patients, amyloid-β-peptide (Aβ) of either 40 or 42 residues are generated by increased activity of β- and γ-secretase. These proteins amalgamate in specific regions of the brain, which disrupts neuronal functions and leads to cognitive impairment. Human umbilical cord blood cells (HUCBC) have proven useful as potential immunomodulatory therapies in various models of neurodegenerative diseases, including AD. Our most recent work studied the impact of umbilical cord blood serum (CBS) on modulation of sAPPα production. Heat-sensitive CBS significantly promoted sAPPα production, indicating that heat-sensitive factor(s) play(s) a role in this process. Liquid chromatography with tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) analysis was used to determine the molecular source of α-secretase in purified CBS and aged blood serum (AgBS) fraction. Of the proteins identified, the subunits of C1 complex (C1q, C1r, and C1s) and alpha-2-macroglobulin showed significantly greater levels in purified α-CBS fraction (α-CBSF) compared with the AgBS fraction (AgBSF). Specifically, C1 markedly increased sAPPα and alpha-carboxyl-terminal fragment (α-CTF) production in a dose-dependent fashion, whereas C1q alone only minimally increased and C3 did not increase sAPPα production in the absence of sera. Furthermore, C1q markedly increased sAPPα and α-CTF, while decreasing Aβ, in CHO/APPwt cells cultured in the presence of whole sera. These results confirm our initial assumption that APP α-secretase activity in human blood serum is mediated by complement C1, opening a potential therapeutic modality for the future of AD.

AkUo3EmK.title: LISPRO mitigates β-amyloid and associated pathologies in Alzheimer's mice.
AkUo3EmK.abstract: Lithium has been marketed in the United States of America since the 1970s as a treatment for bipolar disorder. More recently, studies have shown that lithium can improve cognitive decline associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD). However, the current United States Food and Drug Administration-approved lithium pharmaceutics (carbonate and citrate chemical forms) have a narrow therapeutic window and unstable pharmacokinetics that, without careful monitoring, can cause serious adverse effects. Here, we investigated the safety profile, pharmacokinetics, and therapeutic efficacy of LISPRO (ionic co-crystal of lithium salicylate and l-proline), lithium salicylate, and lithium carbonate (LiCO). We found that LISPRO (8-week oral treatment) reduces β-amyloid plaques and phosphorylation of tau by reducing neuroinflammation and inactivating glycogen synthase kinase 3β in transgenic Tg2576 mice. Specifically, cytokine profiles from the brain, plasma, and splenocytes suggested that 8-week oral treatment with LISPRO downregulates pro-inflammatory cytokines, upregulates anti-inflammatory cytokines, and suppresses renal cyclooxygenase 2 expression in transgenic Tg2576 mice. Pharmacokinetic studies indicated that LISPRO provides significantly higher brain lithium levels and more steady plasma lithium levels in both B6129SF2/J (2-week oral treatment) and transgenic Tg2576 (8-week oral treatment) mice compared with LiCO. Oral administration of LISPRO for 28 weeks significantly reduced β-amyloid plaques and tau-phosphorylation. In addition, LISPRO significantly elevated pre-synaptic (synaptophysin) and post-synaptic protein (post synaptic density protein 95) expression in brains from transgenic 3XTg-AD mice. Taken together, our data suggest that LISPRO may be a superior form of lithium with improved safety and efficacy as a potential new disease modifying drug for AD.

vK5wV5Hz.title: Effect of target current on corrosion resistance of CrN coatings on metal bipolar plates using magnetron sputtering
vK5wV5Hz.abstract: To improve contact resistance and corrosion resistance of the bipole in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC), chromium nitride films were deposited on 304 stainless steel by magnetron sputtering. Effects of the target current on morphology and phase of the Cr xN coatings were investigated. The contact resistance and corrosion resistance of the coatings was tested. The results show that the contact resistance between the modified 304 stainless steel and Toray carbon films is 22.65-24 mΩ/cm 2, within the package force of PEMFC. In the simulative environment of PEMFC (0.05 mol/L H 2SO 4 + 2 mg/L F - on 80°C), the corrosion current of modified bipolar plates is 0.5 × 10 -6 A/cm 2. Increasing the target current can improve the properties of anti-corrosion and conductive on metal bipolar plates.

3XRc4WEx.title: The influence of boron implantation into silicon substrate on the internal stress and adhesion strength of c-BN films
3XRc4WEx.abstract: Cubic boron nitride(c-BN) films were deposited on silicon substrate with boron implanted buffer layer by RF-magnetron sputtering. The most serious problems for c-BN film is high residual stress and low adhesion strength to a substrate. In order to improve the adhesion of the c-BN film, the boron implanted buffer layer was introduced to improve the interface state between the film and substrate. The experiment results showed that the boron implanted buffer layer can reduce the internal stress and improve the adhesion strength of the films obviously. The critical load of scratch test rises to 44.5 N, compared to 7.5 N of c-BN film on the unimplanted silicon. Then the composition and organization of the boron implanted layer was analyzed by XPS. And the influence of boron implanted layer on the internal stress and adhesion strength of c-BN films were investigated.

FeYmURdJ.title: Study on morphology and tribological properties of Ni/n-SiO2 composite coatings by brush plating
FeYmURdJ.abstract: Ni/n-SiO2 compositional coatings were electrodeposited by brush-plating with pulse-reverse current. Morphology, hardness, and tribological properties of the coatings were investigated and compared with those of Ni and composite coatings electrodeposited by brush-plating with direct current. The test results obtained indicate that Ni/n-SiO2 composite coatings electrodeposited by brush-plating with pulse-reverse current, because of the pulse-reverse current and the nano powders, possesses the fine crystal grains, high hardness and low friction coefficient, so it is a better wear-resistant coating.

OBwtzwcF.title: Morphology and tribological properties of Ni/n-SiO<Subscript>2</Subscript> composite coatings by pulse-reverse current brush-plating
OBwtzwcF.abstract:
Ni/n-SiO2 composite coating was electrodeposited by brush-plating with pulse-reverse current(RC). The morphology, hardness, and tribological
 properties of the coating were investigated and compared with those of Ni and composite coatings electrodeposited with direct
 current (DC). The results indicate that Ni/n-SiO2 composite coating electrodeposited by RC, because of RC and the nano powders, has denser coating, finer crystal grains, higher
 hardness (HV650.0, nearly 1.5 times higher than that of Ni coating electrodeposited by DC) and lower friction coefficient
 (nearly 0.62), as a result, in the wearing experiment, the Ni/n-SiO2 composite coating electrodeposited by RC has the least worn loss. So this kind of coating has better wear resistance. And
 RC electro brush-plating can be used as a new technology of brush-plating in the area of wear resistance.

eOK9bLQn.title: Preparation, microstructure and sliding-wear characteristics of brush plated copper–nickel multilayer films
eOK9bLQn.abstract: Cu/Ni multilayer films with sublayer thickness ( h ) ranging from 10 to 1000 nm were prepared on ANSI 1045 steel by brush plating of periodically changing layers of Cu and Ni. The microstructure, composition, microhardness and sliding wear properties against standard SiC ball under unlubricated condition were examined. It was found that the brush plated multilayer films are highly dense and free from porosity. A decrease in h results in smaller grain size and lower coefficient of friction. Both microhardness and wear resistance reach the maximum value when h = 20 nm. Although found with lower hardness compared with brush plated Ni monolayer coating, multilayer films with h ranging from 20 to 80 nm showed improved wear resistance. The increase in the wear resistance was attributed to the combined effect of strengthening of the layer structure and the lubricating of Cu. Research Highlights ► Cu/Ni multilayer films were first fabricated using brush plating technique. ► Tribological properties of brush plated Cu/Ni multilayer films were reported. ► Correlations between sublayer thickness and coating properties were studied. Keywords Electrodeposition Brush plating Cu/Ni multilayers Friction and wear 1 Introduction Over the last few decades, multilayer films with sublayer thickness ( h ) near atomic dimension have attracted a lot of attention in both scientific and engineering communities, as improved techniques for preparing them were developed. These coatings were mainly produced by vacuum deposition [1–3] or electrodeposition from an aqueous solution [4–7] . These techniques, in most cases, offer excellent control of the structure, composition and sublayer thickness of the multilayered coating. The unique control of microstructure provided coatings with enhanced or novel behavior concerning their magnetic, electrical, optical and mechanical properties, which differ considerably from pure metals and homogeneous alloys [8–11] . Although vacuum deposition and sputtering often give excellent controlling of h , applications, especially for tribological use, are restricted because of the high cost and low efficiency. Electrodeposition has shown its advantage in view of the apparatus' simplicity and the ease of controlling the process parameters, especially for metallic multilayered structures  [12] . Electrodeposited Cu/Ni multilayer has long been known for its enhanced hardness and strength compared to corresponding monolayer coatings [13] . Ruff et al. [14,15] found that Cu/Ni multilayer films deposited from sulfamate bath were more wear-resistant than Ni and Cu. Zhang and Xue [16] investigated the grain size strengthening and multilayer effect on wear-resistance for multilayers with h ≥ 10 nm. The brush plating technique, different from conventional bath plating, is an electrochemical process conducted with an electrolyte applied to the substrate by a so-called brush to form the adherent deposit [17] . Compact deposits with small grains are often easily fabricated in a brush plating process. Accordingly, such coatings are often found to be more wear-resistant than conventional electroplated ones [18,19] . Thus, improved tribological properties can also be expected in brush plated multilayer films. However, little work has been reported on preparing multilayer films using brush plating. In this paper, the authors aimed to deposit Cu/Ni multilayer coatings with different sublayer thickness on ANSI 1045 steel with brush plating technique. Structure of the multilayer, as well as tribological properties, including friction coefficient and wear resistance, were then characterized. Effect of the sublayer thickness on tribological behaviors is investigated. 2 Experimental The substrates used for the deposition were Φ 25.4 × 6.0 mm discs of ANSI 1045 steel, polished to a surface roughness less than 0.03 μm. Before the brush plating, all substrates were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone for 10 min and rinsed with deionized water. At room temperature, Ni and Cu were brush plated alternatively from aqueous commercial nickel and ammoniacal copper electrolytes with the composition given in Tables 1 and 2 , respectively. Specimens were rinsed with deionized water as soon as each single sublayer was deposited to make sure that the electrolytes were never polluted. Direct current was applied given by a DGN-3 rectifier for brush plating (AAFE, China). Deposition rates at different voltages, evaluated with the thickness growth per second, were measured to decide the current duration needed to acquire multilayer films with different sublayer thicknesses. The thickness of the alternate layers comprising the multilayer was always equal and the sublayer thicknesses of the multilayer films studied were 10, 20, 40, 80, 160, 500 and 1000 nm. The total thickness of all coating was approximately 20 μm, always keeping Ni the top layer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observations were performed using Quanta 200 scanning electron microscope to study surface morphology, cross-sectional structures and wear scar of the deposits. Specimens for cross-sectional observation were dipped in aqua ammonia to etch Cu sublayer selectively. Energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) analysis was adopted to determine the elements content in the deposits. Elements and grain size of the multilayer films were determined using a D8 Bruker advance X-ray diffractometer (AXS, Germany). A fully calibrated nano indenter (Nano Test 600) was employed to measure the hardness of the deposits, with a load of 15 mN. The hardness values reported here represent an average of five different values taken in different locations of the specimens. The friction and wear tests were conducted under unlubricated condition on a ‘ball on disk’ wear tester (T11, Poland). A schematic presentation of the testing apparatus is shown in Fig. 1 . The rotating lower disk specimen was the brush plated 1045 steel. The stationary upper ball specimen, was made from silicon carbide ceramic, with a diameter of Φ = 6.35 mm and the surface roughness of R a = 0.012 μm. All the tests were conducted at a normal load of 2 N, a rotating radius of 10 mm, a total sliding distance of 90 m and a slide speed of 0.1 m/s. The wear and friction tests were conducted under laboratory atmosphere (room temperature, 25 ± 3 °C, the relative humidity ranged from 50 to 70%). Wear volumes were calculated by measuring the wear trace using an optical microscope (with precision of 0.01 mm). Each test was repeated three times and the average was adopted as the experimental data. Prior to the testing, specimens were ultrasonic cleaned with acetone. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Deposition rate For an accurate control of the sublayer thickness, the deposition rate of both electrolytes at different plating voltages was recorded. Calculated deposition rate (thickness growth per second) was shown in Fig. 2 . No obvious deposition of nickel was found when applied a voltage lower than 2 V. Similarly, Cu could not be deposited from the alkaline cooper solution until the voltage was higher than 1 V. These critical voltage values are connected with the critical deposition overpotential of each metallic ion. For both cases, deposition rate grew with increasing voltage gradually, reaching 45 nm/s at 8 V. Given a higher voltage, the value grew dramatically, reaching 166 nm/s for Ni and 187 nm/s for Cu, at 12 V. In the last phase, with high metallic ion concentration in the electrolyte, which makes sure the ion supply to the cathode surface, the deposition current experienced a rapid increase. However, it is difficult to control the sublayer thickness well in nano scale when the deposition is too fast. Thus, herein, the deposition voltage was kept at 4.0 V for sublayers with thickness above 80 nm and 2.5 V for those with thickness lower than 40 nm. Monolayer coatings of Cu and Ni were also prepared at 4.0 V for comparison. 3.2 SEM analysis Cross-sectional SEM views of films with different sublayer thicknesses ( h ) are shown in Fig. 3 . The lower side in these photos is the substrate. Relative dark bands represent etched Cu sublayers while bright ones the Ni sublayers. It can be seen that both sublayers of Cu and Ni are uniform in thickness except for some flaws induced by the substrate in the internal region. The surface morphology of the substrate played an important role in the initial growth of the deposits. For multilayer films with larger h , the first layers are liable to cracks and other flaws ( Fig. 3 (a)). As the deposits grew thicker, these flaws were soon covered by following sublayers, which are smooth and dense. No crack was observed in multilayer films with lower h . Moreover, most sublayers in the outer area were found to be uniform and parallel to the substrate surface, which is different from those prepared with traditional electrodeposition. In the latter case, sublayers are usually not that uniform in outer region but mostly uniform in internal region of the film [16] . The desirable throwing power of brush plating can be attributed to the friction movements between the anode and the substrate surface, which cleaned the surface and weakened the concentration polarization. Cross-sectional EDS analysis was conducted to determine the elements content in the deposits. Results are shown in Table 3 . The similar content of the two metallic elements in the films of different h confirmed that the thickness ratio was well controlled during the brush plating process. Surface morphology of multilayer films with sublayer thickness varies from 20 nm to 160 nm is shown in Fig. 4 . Surface morphology seems to be well connected with h . Generally, the size of the cauliflower-like grain colony on the surface decreases with h . An average grain colony size of about 800 nm was observed in the coarse surface of multilayer film with h = 160 nm. Fine smooth surface was found in deposits with h as low as 20 nm, with an average grain colony size of about 40 nm. 3.3 XRD analysis The phase composition in the brush plated deposits was characterized by XRD analysis. Fig. 5 shows the XRD pattern of the Cu/Ni multilayer film with h = 20 nm. For comparison purpose, the pattern of brush plated Cu coating is also given in Fig. 6 . Different from the pattern of the single layer Cu coating, the main peaks in the pattern of the multilayer film are the combination of both Cu and Ni peaks. Similar diffraction patterns containing doublet-like peaks with a similar intensity were acquired from all specimens, confirming the existence of distinctive copper and nickel layers, each with its own lattice parameter. Similar peak intensity of Cu and Ni in the pattern of the multilayer film suggests the similar content of the two metals, which shows good consistence with the results of EDS. It is noticed that the brush plated coatings on polycrystalline 1045 steel substrate had strong [111] texture, which is in consistence with previous reports by Zhang [16] and Ghosh [11] . The (111) planes are known to have high atomic density and low surface energy in the Cu and Ni face-centered-cubic crystal system. Thus, these structures of Cu/Ni multilayer film, with predominance of crystals oriented in (111) planes parallel to the substrate, would be beneficial for the coatings obtaining good tribological properties. A broadening of diffraction peaks was observed in the patterns of multilayer films, compared to that of Cu, which is attributed to the decrease in grain size. Scherrer's formula was used to calculate the grain size: (1) D = 0. 9 λ / cos θ β where D is the grain size, λ the wavelength of X-ray used ( λ = 0.154 nm), β the broadening of diffraction line measured at half of its maximum intensity (FWHM) and θ the corresponding angle. Experimental enlargement due to the apparatus was checked with standard reference material (NIST 640 silicon) and a correction of the experimental data was made using Jade software. β of the (111) planes was taken for the calculation. Fig. 7 shows the calculated grain size of Cu and Ni in multilayer films with different h , compared with that of brush plated Ni and Cu monolayer coatings. All brush plated deposits were found to be nano crystalline coatings. Grain size in multilayer films was lower than that in single layer coatings. For both Cu and Ni sublayers, the value was found to decrease gradually with h . Further grain refinement in the multilayered structure can be attributed to the alternative deposition of Cu and Ni, which interrupted the grain growth but promoted the nucleation. This result is in accordance with the SEM surface morphology observations of the coatings. The multilayer with smaller grain size ( D Cu = 11.6 nm, D Ni = 6.7 nm) showed much smoother surface ( Fig. 4 (d)) than that with larger size ( D Cu = 17.0 nm, D Ni = 11.6 nm, Fig. 4 (a)). Such a small grain size contributes to the smooth surface morphology and also may have a beneficial effect on the improvement of the mechanical properties of the coating. 3.3 Microhardness Due to the modulation wavelength of micro-nano scale, when measuring the hardness of brush plated multilayer films, the influence of load has to be taken into account. Finite element analysis [20] showed that measured value was stable when the depth of indentation was no less than 7 times of the modulation wavelength. It was also found the influence of the substrate could be neglected when the depth of indentation was equal to or slightly lower than 1/10 of the film thickness. Thus, the surface microhardness of the deposits was measured by nano indenter. All specimens showed homogeneous surface hardness, with an average deviation less than 5% for all 5 measured values for each specimen. The relationship between the average hardness of the coating and sublayer thickness is shown in Fig. 8 , compared with brush plated Cu and Ni monolayer coatings. The average hardness of the multilayer films was found to be in the range of 3.0–3.7 GPa. Several studies have shown a strengthened hardness of multilayer Cu/Ni structure compared with single layer Ni coatings [16] . However, as shown in our experiments, all brush plated multilayer films showed a hardness lower than that of Ni (4.8 GPa) only higher than that of Cu (2.8 GPa). It was also observed that the hardness increases gradually with the decreasing sublayer thickness, meeting the maximum value when h = 20 nm. The strengthening of multilayered structure was mostly attributed to the inhibition of dislocation movements by the interface. Several mechanisms have been put forward. (a) Image force theory by Koehler [21] claimed that the difference of Young's modulus near the interface induced the image force, which acted on the dislocations. (b) Orowan [22] insisted that the resistance of the dislocation movement was from the interface, that is, the alternating stress field formed by coherent stress and thermal stress at the interface. (c) Hall–Petch theory claimed that the hardness and the modulation wavelength follow the Hall–Petch relationship [23,24] . (d) Cheng's mismatch dislocation theory [20] pointed out that the hindrance of mismatch dislocation to other dislocations gives rise to the hindrance of the interface. For a further understanding of the strengthening mechanisms, the relationship between microhardness and h −1/2 is described in Fig. 9 . It can be seen that when h > 80 nm, the relationship between microhardness and h −1/2 followed the linear Hall–Petch equation. The data were least-squares straight-line fitted with intercept HV 0 = 2.89 GPa, the rate of slope K HV = 0.477 GPa/nm −1/2 . In case that h < 80 nm, the hardness and h followed a nonlinear relationship. A maximum value of 3.72 GPa was found when h = 20 nm. Further decrease of h reduced the microhardness. Similar results were reported by Zhang, et al. [16] in the study of electrodeposited Cu/Ni multilayer films using single bath method. When h > 80 nm, from the Hall–Petch formula HV = HV 0 + K HV ·h −1/2 , the value of HV 0 (2.89 MPa) is similar to the microhardness of Cu (2.84 MPa). It indicates that the deformation of the multilayer films was mainly caused by the dislocation gliding in the Cu sublayers, which are relatively soft. Strengthening was mostly from the hindrance of the interfaces. According to breeding and pile-up theory of dislocation, the hardness increases with the increasing interface density. This can be achieved by lower down the modulation wavelength, or sublayer thickness. However, when h = 10 nm, microhardness decreases to a lower value of 3.3 GPa, which is similar with the value when h = 160 nm. It is known that the mutual solubility of Cu and Ni is very high. For the multilayer film with h = 10 nm, due to the impact of the interface width, the layered structure is not as distinct as those with higher h . The resistance to the dislocation movement is thus lower in this coating, which gave rise to the decrease in microhardness. Thus, throughout the sublayer thickness range in our experiments, the correlation of y = a x 2 + b x + c between the microhardness ( y ) and h −1/2 ( x ) is more likely to be followed, as shown in Fig. 9 . 3.4 Tribological properties Coefficient of friction (COF) as a function of the sublayer thickness h is shown in Fig. 10 . COF of all multilayer films were found to be lower than that of the single layer Ni coating (0.85) but higher than that of the Cu coating (0.25). COF decreases with the decreasing of h , with the maximum value of 0.82 ( h = 1000 nm), which is similar to that of Ni, and the minimum value of 0.33 ( h = 10 nm), which is slightly higher than that of Cu. Wear-caused volume loss is shown in Fig. 11 . The wear volume was calculated with the following formula: (2) Δ V = 2 π r ⋅ R 2 arcsin d 2 R − 1 2 d R 2 − 1 4 d 2 where Δ V is the wear volume, R is the radius of the SiC ball, d is the width of the wear scar and r is the rotating radius. It is noticed that the wear loss was in good dependence with the sublayer thickness h . For all cases with h ≥ 20 nm, the wear volume decreased with the decreasing of h . When h ≥ 160 nm, the wear resistance of multilayer films higher than that of Cu but lower than that of Ni showed a simply combined property of the two constituent metals. When 80 nm ≥ h ≥ 20 nm, the wear volume of the multilayer films was lower than that of both single layer coatings. The minimum value was achieved when h = 20 nm, which is only 1/12 of that of Cu and 1/3 of that of Ni. Multilayer films with sublayer thickness in nano scale showed an improved wear resistance. However, for the multilayer film with the sublayer thickness as low as 10 nm, the value increased to 0.12 mm 3 , even higher than that of the film with h = 160 nm. This might be attributed to the decreased microhardness when h = 10 nm. The wear of the deposits is a complex process which is dependent on various factors. For Cu/Ni multilayer films, the wear resistance was mainly affected by numerous interfaces in the deposits and the different mechanical and tribological properties of Cu and Ni. Fig. 12 gives wear scar morphologies of multilayer films with different h , compared with Cu and Ni coatings. Films with h > 80 nm showed similar wear scar morphology with that of pure Ni, indicating grinding abrasion as the main mechanism. However, the deposit with h = 20 nm exhibited the characteristic of laminar tearing, suggesting an improved wear resistance. EDS analysis of the wear scar showed that the adhered debris were mostly Cu. The debris was from Cu sublayer in the deposits. Transfer and adhesion of Cu during the wear process formed a lubricating layer between surfaces of the specimens and the counterpart, which resulted in the decrease of COF. Two main factors seem to cause the improved wear-resistance of Cu/Ni multilayer films: (a) an increase in the interface number of multilayers by decreasing the sublayer thickness, which generated the barriers of dislocation glide through the interface between adjacent layers of copper and nickel; and (b) a decrease in the grain size of the multilayer by decreasing the sublayer thickness, as verified by the XRD analysis. Moreover, tribological properties of brush plated Cu/Ni multilayers are more likely to be determined by combined effect of both interface effect and Cu-introduced lubrication. Generally, dislocation density increases with the decreasing of h , which implies better wear resistance. However, when h is lower than the critical thickness, because of the well mutual solubility between Cu and Ni, diffusion across the interface weakens the interface effect. 4 Conclusions Cu/Ni multilayer films with various sublayer thickness were brush plated on the 1045 steel. From experiments and analysis above, following conclusions have been reached: (1) Smooth and uniform Cu/Ni multilayer films can be fabricated using brush plating technique. The growth of multilayers had a predominance of crystals oriented with (111) planes parallel to the substrate. The grain size of multilayer films became small with the decrease in the sublayer thickness. (2) All multilayer films show microhardness higher than that of Cu monolayer coating but lower than that of Ni monolayer coating. Brush plated multilayers exhibit an intermediate property compared to Cu and Ni monolayer coatings. Above the critical sublayer thickness value of 20 nm, the microhardness of the multilayers increased with decreasing sublayer thickness. (3) All multilayer films show an average COF lower than that of Ni monolayer coating but higher than that of Cu monolayer coating. The average COF decreased when h became smaller. Deposits with sublayer thickness varies from 20 to 80 nm showed improved wear-resistance, due to increased number of interfaces, which give rise to improved hardness, as well as the lubricating effect of Cu. pegRZX9z.title: Corrosion resistance of brush plated Pb/Ni multilayer coatings in a simulated environment of PEMFC
pegRZX9z.abstract: Pb/Ni multilayer coatings, with either Pb or Ni as the top layer, were brush plated on ANSI 304 stainless steel to improve its performance as bipolar plates in polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFC). Surface morphology and cross-sectional microstructure of the coatings were characterized with scanning electron microscope (SEM) and optical microscope, respectively. The corrosion resistance of brush plated coatings in a simulated PEMFC environment was investigated using both three-electrode method and immersion of 300 h. Coating surfaces after the immersion were characterized with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). The results show that the multilayer coatings were smooth, dense, and small in grain size with clear layered structure. In the simulated PEMFC environment, the corrosion of multilayer coatings was mainly uniform corrosion. Coatings with different top layers exhibit different corrosion behaviors. Ni layer was corroded preferentially as the anode while the Pb layer was protected. © (2010) Trans Tech Publications.

9gj7U2Mh.title: Corrosion resistance of composite coatings prepared by pulse-reverse electro-plating
9gj7U2Mh.abstract: The Ni/n-Al 2O 3 coatings were made by pulse-reverse electro-plating. Morphology, porosity and corrosion resistant properties were examined respectively. Compared with coatings by other processes, the Ni/n-Al 2O 3 coating by pulse-reverse electro-plating showed better properties.

lIU7FzEw.title: Experimental study of nano-composite superhard TiN/Si3N4 films prepared by ion beam assisted deposition
lIU7FzEw.abstract: The multiphase nano-commposite coatings consisting of nanocrystalline TiN and amorphous Si3N4 were deposited on silicon substrate by means of ion beam assisted deposition. The influences of current density, ion energy, the area ratio of Ti to Si on microhardness of TiN/Si3N4 films were studied. Both composition and structure of the composite films were analyzed by nanoindenter, XPS and XRD. The surface morphology of the TiN/Si3N4 films was observed by AFM. Then the growth mechanism of TiN/Si3N4 films was discussed.

5e82xXob.title: Adhesion improvement of cubic boron nitride film on high speed steel substrate by BNX implanted buffer interlayer
5e82xXob.abstract: One of the major problems for the deposition of cubic boron nitride(c-BN) films on W6Mo5Cr4V2 high speed steels(HHS) is the poor adhesion of the film to the substrate. For the purpose of improving adhesion, the BN X implanted buffer layer was introduced between the HSS and c-BN film deposited by the RF-magnetron sputtering. The influence of the BN X buffer layer on adhesion was investigated and the results showed that when the N/B ratio of the buffer layer is about 1:1, the adhesive strength of c-BN film to the HHS substrate reached the maximum, about 28.47 N, which is sixteen times higher than that of c-BN film deposited without the buffer layer. According to the XPS analysis, the surface of buffer interlayer was mainly in BN phase, which is the main reason to reduce the internal stress and improve the adhesion strength of c-BN films.

3KmR3y95.title: Adhesion improvement of cubic boron nitride film on high speed steel substrate implanted by boron element
3KmR3y95.abstract: Cubic boron nitride (c-BN) films were deposited on W6Mo5Cr4V2 high speed steel (HSS) substrate implanted with boron ion by RF-magnetron sputtering. The films were analyzed by the bending beam method, scratch test, XPS and AFM. The experimental results show that the implantation of boron atom can reduce the internal stress and improve the adhesion strength of the films. The critical load of scratch test rises to 27.45 N, compared to 1.75 N of c-BN film on the unimplanted HSS. The AFM shows that the surface of the c-BN film on the implanted HSS is low in roughness and small in grain size. Then the composition of the boron implanted layer was analyzed by the XPS. And the influence of the boron implanted layer on the internal stress and adhesion strength of c-BN films were investigated.

32KeA5Fd.title: Corrosion resistance of Ni/n - SiO2 composite coatings by pulse-reverse brush plating
32KeA5Fd.abstract: The Ni/n - SiO2 coating was deposited by pulse - reverse brush plating. The surface morphology of the coating was analyzed by SEM, the porosity of the coating was evaluated and the corrosion resistance of the coating was measured in the solution of sea water. The corrosion mechanism of the coating was also discussed. The result shows that, compared with Ni and Ni/n - SiO2 coatings deposited by direct current, the Ni/n - SiO2 coating by pulse - reverse current has much compact and finer surface morphology, lower porosity and better corrosion resistance.

p8zSYF36.title: Influence of boron buffer implantation layer on growth of BN films
p8zSYF36.abstract: Cubic boron nitride (c-BN) films were deposited on the high speed steel (HSS) substrate implanted with boron ion by RF-magnetron sputtering. The films were analyzed by IR, XPS and AFM. The experiment results show that the implantation of boron ions into silicon substrate can reduce the internal stress of films, and when the boron dose is appropriate, the implantation of boron into HSS substrate will be helpful to synthesize c-BN phase and reduce the internal stress of films. AFM shows that the surface roughness of the c-BN film on the implanted HSS is lower and the grain size is smaller. Besides, the phase structure of the boron implanted layer was analyzed by XPS, and the influence of boron implanted layer on the growth of c-BN films was investigated.

IIxrJyXb.title: Study on Synthesis and Analysis of Methyltriacetoxysilane
IIxrJyXb.abstract: Methyltriacetoxysilane,a kind of crosslinking agent used for RTV silicone rubber,was prepared by reaction of methyltrichlorosilane with acetic anhydrid.This improved procedure is very simple,convenient to operate and control for industrial process with low cost.The yield of the product was more than 96%,with a purity value of above 97% by GC analysis and the residual chlorine content was less than 50ppm.
